render.tex: \title{Cartesian Product of Sets} What does $A\times B$ mean when $A$ and $B$ are both sets?

reason.tex:
%text Given two \underline\text{non-empty} sets $A$ and $B$, we define $A\times B$ as the \underline\text{set of all ordered pairs} $(x,y)$ where $x\in A$ and $y\in B$ Symbolically, we write this as \[ \quad A\times B = \left\lbrace (x,y)\,\vert\, x\in A, y\in B \right\rbrace\] Now, some examples % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNN}
\hline A & B & A\times B \\ \hline \left\lbrace 1,2\right\rbrace & \left\lbrace 3,4\right\rbrace & \left\lbrace (1,3),(1,4),(2,3),(2,4) \right\rbrace\\ \hline \left\lbrace a\right\rbrace & \left\lbrace b,c\right\rbrace & \left\lbrace (a,b),(a,c)\right\rbrace \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text Once again, $A\times B$ is also a set. But it is a set of elements like $(a,b)$ instead of just $a$ or $b$ Moreover, the idea can be extended to finding $A\times B\times C$ The set $A\times B\times C$ will made up of elements like $(a,b,c)$%
